column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182429,2017,Mathematics for Liberal Arts & Science,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. G.M. Terra-Bleeker'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this course students are able to:

column2: • investigate and visualize functions of one or two variables,
• use inverse trigonometric functions and logarithms,
• differentiate a broad set of standard functions, using product, quotient and chain rules,
• solve (systems of) linear and quadratic equations,
• perform basic matrix calculations, including 2x2 inverses and arbitrary determinants,
• optimize functions of one or more variables, with and without constraint,
• integrate linear combinations of standard functions including linear substitutions,
• work with probabilities and some basic discrete and continuous probability distributions.
<head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column4: This course introduces students to a large number of elementary but important mathematical concepts and techniques that have a wide range of applications in natural and social sciences. They acquire the quantitative reasoning and mathematical manipulations skills required for courses in life, medical, and earth sciences, as well as several sub-disciplines within social sciences such as economics, psychology, sociology, and political sciences. Topics include basic and discrete mathematics, matrices, graphs and derivatives, functions of multiple variables and (constrained) optimization, basic integration with applications on probability distributions.

In addition to the four class hours a week spent on lectures and guided practical work, students are expected to work for ten hours a week on average on self-study reading and problem solving, doing take-home assignments to be handed in and studying for the exams.

column2: </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182469,2017,Mathematics for poets, thinkers, and doers",English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. G.M. Terra-Bleeker'],,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: After completing this course students are able to:

column5: discuss what mathematics is really about on a conceptual level.
recognize various methodologies and famous problems within mathematics.
think logically and effectively by finding non-computational solutions to various problems in logic and mathematics.
formulate rigorous proofs in simple settings.
apply logic skills to non-mathematical endeavors such as analyzing an argument.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: Doing math should be fun. In this course, students overcome “math anxiety” through pure thought. Rather than memorize formulae and theory, they seek to answer the question “what is mathematics?” by finding solutions to mathematically tinged puzzles and fundamental questions. This course stays away from technical calculations people usually associate with mathematics, but it does provide you with fundamental challenges to be engaged with pure thought and logical reasoning. The real surprise is that these logic exercises prove useful. Eugene P. Wigner, one of the great mathematical physicists of the twentieth century, said as much when he referenced “the unreasonable effectiveness of mathematics.”

The course covers a number of themes that correlate to chapters in the textbook: fun and games, geometric explorations, number contemplation, infinite sets and deformable objects, chaos theory or probability theory. Students prepare for each class through reading material and solving problems set to be presented in class to create an interactive problem dialog. They also complete a term project, which consists of studying a mathematical topic of their choice and presenting their work in a short report and a poster presentation for the rest of the class. In addition to the four weekly contact hours, each student is expected to devote ten hours to the course each week, reading the textbook, solving problems and working on their term project.

column2: </body>

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182568,2017,Measuring Behaviour,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. J. de Vries'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing the module the student should have a profound understanding of:

column2: • Types of problems in animal behaviour research.
• Measures of behavior.
• Recording methods.
• Reliability and validity of measures.
• Empirical cycle.
• Research design.
• Statistical analysis of data.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The purpose of this course (1 week) is to acquire working knowledge of the methods for measuring and analysing animal behaviour.
The course is based on the book ""Measuring Behaviour. An introductory guide"".
Day 1: Introduction; practising observational methods; self-study
Day 2: Empirical cycle; research design; self-study
Day 4: Practising the statistical analysis of behavioural data; self-study
On day 3 students have to answer a set of questions pertaining to methodological issues in one or two papers, preferably related to their Masters study topic.

The course is not a course in statistics. Basic knowledge on statistical tests is presumed. On day 4 the application of some tests frequently used in behavioural biology will be reviewed. The emphasis here is on when to use which test and how to perform the test in SPSS.

Send an e-mail to the course coordinator (Dr. J. de Vries, j.devries1@uu.nl). The mail should contain 1) your name; 2) student number; 3) e-mail address; 4) telephone number; 5) current Master track. Please note: the number of participants is limited to 25. Only the first registrations can be accepted.
Mandatory for students in Master’s programme: YES

Optional for students in other Master’s programmes GS-LS: Neuroscience and Cognition, especially the tracks Cognitive Neuroscience and Behavioural Neuroscience; Environmental Biology, especially the specialization programme Behavioural Ecology; and any other master programme with relevant basal courses.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/184089,2017,Mechanism-based Veterinary Pharmacology and Toxicology (elective course),English,Faculty of Veterinary Medicine,,['dr. H.P.M. Vijverberg'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Acquiring profound knowledge on current scientific topics in (veterinary) pharmacology and toxicology.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This elective course provides an opportunity for MSc students to acquire profound, knowledge on current scientific topics in (veterinary) pharmacology and toxicology and provides background and training to master the process to do so. Apart from specific expertise, participation in this course will contribute a critical attitude and skills in assessing and evaluating pharmacological and toxicological effects and teach you to pose the right questions for elaborating translational aspects of drugs and toxicants (life-long learning).

Each topic of this course departs from a recent high-interest scientific finding in (veterinary) pharmacology and toxicology and is an exercise to recognize, describe and present its potential value for future application in veterinary medicine. As a participant you will select and study one topic from literature, resulting in a written report. In the process, you will provide feed-back to other students working on different topics on the choices made, the approach taken, and the results obtained and you will receive such feedback yourself. This active role is an important part of the course and will be considered in the final assessment. Although this elective is designed as a stand-alone module, you may consider elaborating a subject linked to your personal interest or fitting with your MSc track. Selected high-interest topics are offered in the detailed course info. Please note that for elaborating a topic of your personal preference, you will need to inquire at least one month in advance of the start of the course (late proposals will not be considered). The course is suited for students from all stages in the MSc track.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/193038,2017,Mechanisms of Disease,English,University College Roosevelt,,[],,
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182419,2017,Mechanisms of Diseases,English,University College Utrecht,,['drs. C.J.G. Sanders'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: After completing this course students are able to:

column5: illustrate the principles of the mechanisms of diseases.
derive the symptoms of failures in the system or the pathofysiology based on a particular scenario so as to diagnosis a hypothetical patient.
draw upon a basis of medical knowledge and experience.
summarize the aspects of each organ system, both for oral presentations and in the form of written abstract.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: This course examines the relation between the normal functioning (physiology) and disease (pathophysiology) of seven basic organ systems: 1. heart and blood vessels (cardiology, arteriosclerosis), 2. lung (pulmonology), 3. kidney (nephrology), 4. gastro intestinal tract, 5. endocrine glands (endocrinology), 6. the central nervous system, and 7. the reproductive system.  To demonstrate the relation between two or more organ systems, the course ends with a study of diabetes, which involves aspects of endocrinology and the cardiovascular and nervous system.

Students are expected to spend about ten hours per week on the course outside of class. Lectures are dedicated to introducing course materials and preparing students for their assignments. Students complete several reports about an aspect of embryology, anatomy, physiology and pathofysiology, and report their findings to the class. Student presentations are subjected to peer and teacher assessment.

After receiving an overview of various organs systems and diseases, students begin to recognize the symptoms a patient will show when a particular organ fails. The instructor demonstrates a real diagnosis at the University Hospital. Though the course does not emphasize clinical skills, students participate actively during this demonstration.

column2: </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179729,2017,Mechanisms of deformation and transport in rocks,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['dr. A.R. Niemeijer', 'dr. C.J. Peach']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The course aims to provide a state-of-the-art background in materials science, as needed:

column2: • to interpret field and experimental data and observations on rock behaviour at a quantitative, mechanistic level;
• to critically evaluate current research literature on rock deformation and physical properties;
• to construct models of rock and fault behaviour under conditions relevant to the crust and mantle;
• to apply such models in the solution of geological, geophysical, geo-technical and geo-resources problems;
• to begin independent research in the field and/or laboratory.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Large scale deformation and fluid or melt transport phenomena occurring within the Earth's crust and mantle are ultimately controlled by processes operating at the micro- and mesoscopic scales. Therefore, in order to model large scale dynamic processes operating in the crust and mantle, and to interpret deformation- and transport-related structures preserved in rocks, an understanding of the mechanisms of deformation and transport that operate in Earth materials is needed.

This course addresses such mechanisms, using an advanced materials science approach. It forms a core component of the Earth Materials Track within the Master Programme Earth Structure & Dynamics (ESD). It is also a useful and frequent choice for students following other ESD tracks.
Properties of geofluids; fluid/melt transport through rock; electrical conductivity of rock; percolation theory; Effects of deformation and microstructural change on transport properties.

Elastic behaviour and thermodynamics of stressed solids; Defects and diffusion; Diffusion creep, superplasticity, deformation of solid/liquid/melt systems; Dislocation dynamics and intracrystalline plastic flow; Microstructure, recrystallization and deformation fabrics; Fracture mechanics and failure of rocks and ceramics;  Fault slip, friction and slip-stability; Deformation behaviour of key rock materials under crustal and mantle conditions.
Throughout the course, examples will be given of applications in Geology, Geophysics, Geo-resources and Geo-storage.

column2: • Ability to work in the team: Students will complete mini-projects and assignments in teams of two and are encouraged to interact with other teams to discuss the problems investigated.  Within this structure, students must distribute tasks and organize their workflow and time planning.
• Written communication: Each mini-project or practical assignment results in a written product (report) that must be completed and handed in by a strict deadline..

• Problem solving: The mini-projects, practicals and homework exercises given are extremely challenging and require creativity and imagination to envisage which processes have to be considered and how to describe them quantitatively.
• Verbal communication skills: Students are strongly encouraged to participate in actively answering questions posed by the lecturers in class.

• Work ethic.  The deadlines for completing mini-project/practical and homework exercises are extremely strict so that worked answers can be distributed to all students but only when all students have submitted a given product. Failure to be professional in meeting these deadlines results in disqualification from the course.

• Analytical / quantitative skills: The miniprojects/practicals and homework exercises involve breaking complex problems, in the field of deformation and transport properties, down into their component parts, first conceptually.   The conceptual components must then be systematically described using suitable equations and parameter values, introduced in the lectures, to arrive at quantitative answers.
• These will be continuously assessed on a pass/fail basis
• All assignments (pr + hw) given must be completed with a “pass” to pass the course
• Where appropriate and possible, feedback will include worked answers for self-study
• All assignments given (practicals and homework) must be completed with a “pass” to pass the course
• The final grade is based on two written, closed-book examinations and is calculated as follows: Mid term exam Peach 37.5% + Final exam Niemeijer 62.5%

• The minimum pass grade (weighted average of Parts Peach and Niemeijer) for the course is 5.5 out of 10, with all assignments completed. Grades between 5.50 and 5.99 are rounded up to 6.0. A grade of 5.49 or less is a fail.

• The right to a repair examination is granted if the unrounded average grade for Parts 1 and 2 lies between 4.00 and 5.49 and if the student has completed and obtained a pass for all assignments. Repair exams may address Part 1 (Peach) or Part 2 (Niemeijer) – students may choose which they prefer to resit (one only). After the repair exam, the final course grade is calculated as the average of the grades obtained for Parts 1 and 2, with the repaired grade updated. If the course grade obtained is 5.50 or above it will be set at 6.0, i.e. no final scores higher than 6.0 are given. If the final grade is 5.49 or less, the result is a fail and the entire course has be redone if a pass is sought.

• The right to a repair exam is not automatic if a student is ill.  De-registering for an exam or test due to illness does not automatically entitle students to take a repair test or exam.  After recovery, the student must supply a doctor’s note certifying that the student was ill on the day of the test/exam. Without this, students have no right to a repair exam.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178843,2017,Media Materialities,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['prof. dr. D.A. Pascoe'],,Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: The course aims to develop interdisciplinary methodological approaches to illuminate the role of mediality in the formation of cultural and aesthetic meaning. Within this framework, students will explore the interplay between analogue and digital materialities in a range of cultural manifestations, including works of literature, film, exhibitions and and philosophy.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Concepts such as materiality, mediality and intermediality are widely circulated, and the critical energy which propels them can be attributed to an increasing consciousness of the degree to which modern culture has been embedded in a range of different technologies; and specifically in the form of those media forms through which the specifically human has materialised over the last century or so.

This  course aims to provide a basic knowledge of the fundamental connections between literature and  the technologies that have framed and disseminated it, from the Enlightenment onwards. Examining a variety of media, ancient and modern, in relation to texuality the module explores those moments of transition when technologies were not yet defined in relation to institutions of literature.

Travelling beyond the mere history of cultural and technological innovations, the course considers how the devices and desires of communication can frame a collective idea of public and private; examines the proposition that human interaction and identity formation thus cannot be thought independently of surrounding media and technology. and suggests how such conceptions inform our understanding of the materialisations of the ""Real' .

Specifically: students are made aware of the professionalisation of culture, both in theory and practice. Generally: this course serves as preparation for a PhD program in the Humanities as well as for non-academic careers, by training the following transferable skills [list]

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/181502,2017,Media and Persuasion in Premodern Europe,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. F. van den Eijnde', 'dr. K. Laveant', 'dr. M.D. Veldhuizen', 'prof. dr. A.A.M. Besamusca']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: - students will gain a general understanding of the historical developments in:
- media (oral, textual, visual) in premodern Europe
- students will gain insight in current methodological and theoretical debates in cultural history
- students will train their research skills in working with premodern sources</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Persuasion is a crucial but also elusive force in European history. This course explores how individuals created, developed and applied forms of persuasion through different media of communication. It focuses in particular on textual, visual and oral media and the significance of the rhetorical tradition. We will address questions such as: how did rulers, writers, painters and preachers try to persuade their audiences? What is the significance of charisma? How can we study the persuasive power of historical sources? </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/181177,2017,Media and the Making of the Modern World,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. J. Verheul', 'dr. J.B. Hung']",,"Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179978,2017,Media and Society,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['D.A. Hassler-Forest', 'dr. A. Meuzelaar', 'dr. P.J.C. Romondt Vis', 'drs. B. Beijnon', 'H.D.H.A. Zijlstra']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
De student kan kernbegrippen uit de mediatheorie (zoals agency, discours, identiteit, ideologie, interpellatie) in eigen woorden uitleggen.
De student kan de theorieën over de ontwikkeling van massamedia en de wisselwerking tussen media en maatschappij beschrijven.
De student kan centrale concepten uit de mediatheorie demonstreren aan de hand van de concrete vormen van massamedia.
De student kan in een kort essay (max. 600 woorden) een onderbouwde kritische houding ten opzichte van de rol van massamedia in de maatschappij innemen en verwoorden.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>De cursus geeft een historisch georiënteerd overzicht van theorie en kritiek met betrekking tot massamedia in de 20e en 21e eeuw. Het vormt een inleiding in de beginselen van kritische mediatheorie, met veel aandacht voor de industriële en institutionele kaders waarbinnen massamedia (krant, radio, film, televisie, games) in de laatste 120 jaar zelf zijn gevormd, en op hun beurt een vormende werking hebben gehad. De strekking, inhoud, en relevantie van de verschilllende theoretische begrippen worden uitgelegd aan de hand van hedendaagse en herkenbare voorbeelden uit het medialandschap, en schrijf- en analysevaardigheden worden in werkgroepsverband geoefend door middel van concrete case studies die aan de studenten worden aangereikt.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/181172,2017,Media and the Making of the Modern World,Dutch, English",Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. J. Verheul', 'dr. J.B. Hung', 'K.H.M. Olijslager']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Dit is een blok waarin studenten veel lezen en academische literatuur bestuderen over de rol van massamedia in de moderne cultuur. Zij leren hoe ze aan de hand van academische concepten zoals framing en mediatisering de studie van massamedia in verband kunnen brengen met relevante aspecten van de moderne geschiedenis, zoals verstedelijking, nationalisme en identiteitsvorming. Ook de rol van journalisten en mediacritici wordt onder de loep genomen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177920,2017,Media and Participation,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['A.M Kustritz', 'B. Vertommen', 'D.A. Hassler-Forest', 'dr. P.J.C. Romondt Vis']",,"Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: Bij goed gevolg van deze cursus hebben/kunnen studenten:
- kennis van de participatievormen van oude en nieuwe media en de theoretische, politieke, sociale, culturele en ethische kanten hiervan.
- kritisch reflecteren op het wetenschappelijk en maatschappelijk debat omtrent media en participatie en kunnen ze een wetenschappelijk onderbouwde bijdrage aan deze debatten leveren.
- met behulp van de opgedane theoretische en methodische kennis een klein onderzoek uitvoeren naar een specifieke casus binnen het onderzoeksveld</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De opkomst van participatieve mediavormen heeft de rollen van mediaproducenten en mediagebruikers geherdefinieerd. Volgens een optimistisch perspectief worden consumenten medeproducenten; burgers hebben toegang tot uiteenlopende platvormen waar zij bij kunnen dragen aan het maatschappelijke debat en de opinievorming als blogger, burger-journalist of gewoon als user die een Facebook-pagina onderhoudt of twittert. Volgens een pessimistisch perspectief echter, worden burgers en consumenten via participatieve media alleen maar beter tot consumptie verleid, raken ze hun privacy kwijt en worden ze als gratis producenten van content uitgebuit.

In deze cursus onderzoeken we de participatievormen van oude en nieuwe media nader. Daarbij kijken wij naar de politieke, sociale, culturele en ethische kanten van de toenemende ‘mediatisering’ van maatschappelijke processen en het alledaagse leven. Ook onderzoeken we het actuele maatschappelijke en wetenschappelijke debat hierover, uitgaande van de volgende vragen: Wie heeft er in welke mate toegang tot de productie en distributie van informatie in een ‘participatiesamenleving’? Welke nieuwe participatievormen zijn er met de komst van Web 2.0 ontstaan, hoe zijn deze verweven met de oude media? Welke nieuwe verdienmodellen gaan daarmee gepaard? Wat moet een gebruiker kunnen en weten om participatieve mediavormen competent te benutten?
​Deze cursus is het  4<sup>e</sup> vak in Verdiepingspakket ‘Media, communicatie en markt’</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177936,2017,Media and Audience: Qualitative Research,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. W. Sanders'],,Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: After finishing the course the student is able to:
- Set up and conduct a qualitative reseach, formulate a basic research question and analyse qualitative data systematically

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In deze cursus staan de empirische implicaties van de andere,  meer theoretisch en/of analytisch georiënteerde cursussen centraal. We concentreren ons op een bepaald aspect van receptieprocessen, waarbij altijd de analytische vaardigheden van de studenten ingezet worden om hypotheses te formuleren over reacties van het publiek op verschillende media-uitingen. Het accent kan bijvoorbeeld liggen op vraagstukken met betrekking tot burgerschap en informatieve films en programma’s (nieuwsbulletins, voorlichtingfilms, documentaires, discussieprogramma’s, etc.), of op identiteitsvorming middels identificatie met (fictieve) personages. De cursus richt zich op de training van kwalitatieve onderzoekvaardigheden die nodig zijn om de brug te slaan tussen de Geesteswetenschappen en de Sociale Wetenschappen. We concentreren ons op methoden die vaak in marktonderzoek gebruikt worden (focusgroeponderzoek en de  hardop-denkmethode). Veel aandacht zal uitgaan naar de systematische analyse van kwalitatieve data en het construeren van wetenschappelijke modellen op basis van die analyses. Bovendien is arbeidsmarktoriëntatie een belangrijk aspect (bijv. door het uitvoeren van opdrachten van culturele instellingen, bedrijven en organisaties).
Deze cursus is het  3e vak in Verdiepingspakket ‘Media, communicatie en markt’
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177919,2017,Media and Representation,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. E. Mueller'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na goed gevolg van de cursus kan de student:
- met behulp van theoretische begrippen uitleggen waarom we media-uitingen niet als weerspiegeling van de werkelijkheid zien, maar als constructies van (de betekenis) van die werkelijkheid
- een relevante case selecteren voor een representatie-analyse en op basis daarvan een adequate onderzoeksvraag stellen
- mediarepresentaties adequaat analyseren in het kader van aangereikte theoretische en methodologische kaders.
- van de analyse consistent verslag leggen binnen de geldende wetenschappelijk conventies.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Audiovisuele media representeren de werkelijkheid, sterker nog: er zijn veel aspecten van de werkelijkheid waarvan wij alleen via audiovisuele media kennis kunnen nemen. Maar mediale representaties in fotografie, film, televisie, video en op internet - zijn geenszins neutrale weerspiegelingen van de wereld: mediale representaties zijn het resultaat van complexe technologische, semiotische, retorische en ideologische processen. Deze cursus legt daarom de nadruk op het analyseren van representatiestrategieën in uiteenlopende audiovisuele teksten (o.m. televisieprogramma's, documentaires, nieuwsberichten, films, blogs, etc.) met als doel het maatschappelijke en culturele 'werk' van representaties beter te begrijpen. Studenten leren mediateksten te analyseren als informatie- als betekenisdragers waarvan de vormgeving bepaald wordt (1) door communicatieve doelstellingen, (2) door mediaspecifieke conventies en (3) door cultureel gedeelde discoursen over de onderwerpen die in een mediale representatie aan bod komen. De cursus heeft als doel studenten theorieën, analytische concepten en methoden aan te reiken om de retorica van met name audiovisuele teksten te kunnen analyseren, en kritisch te kunnen reflecteren op mediale representatie-strategieën.
Deze cursus is het 2e vak in Verdiepingspakket ‘Media, communicatie en markt’
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178626,2017,Media in Transition,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. N. Verhoeff'],,Course goals

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: In de cursus ontwikkelt de student
1.) inzicht in, en reflectie op ontwikkelingen van media en historische “transities” binnen het (audiovisuele) medialandschap van de afgelopen 50 jaar
2.) inzicht in de rol van concepten gehanteerd binnen het mediawetenschappelijke debat voor het beschrijven en begrijpen van deze historische veranderingen.

Na afloop van de cursus heeft de student onderzoeksvaardigheden ontwikkeld, zoals met name: het verwerken van theoretische mediawetenschappelijke teksten; het vergelijken van verschillende onderzoeksperspectieven en concepten; en het in kaart brengen van een zelf bepaald deelgebied binnen het mediawetenschappelijk debat omtrent media in transitie in de vorm van een individueel geschreven overzichtsartikel.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Door de zogenoemde digitale revolutie hebben we productie, distributie en receptie van films en televisieprogramma’s in de afgelopen jaren in razend snel tempo zien veranderen. Ingrijpende veranderingsprocessen binnen het medialandschap zijn echter geen recent verschijnsel. Sinds de komst van film in de beginjaren van de 20e eeuw en de latere opkomst van televisie in de jaren 50 is het Nederlands medialandschap voortdurend in beweging geweest. De komst van geluid, de afstandsbediening, video, 3D technologie, mobiele media – deze technologische ontwikkelingen maar ook nieuwe en veranderende mediapraktijken maken onze media (‘film’, ‘televisie’, ‘video’, etc.) tot veranderende objecten.

In deze cursus zullen studenten in onderlinge samenwerking hedendaagse veranderingsprocessing binnen het (audiovisueel) medialandschap in verband met de toenemende digitalisering van productie, distributie en vertoning in kaart brengen en kritisch reflecteren op het mediawetenschappelijke debat over deze veranderingen.

In deze cursus werk je samen in teamverband en verdiep je professionele onderzoeksvaardigheden en (mondelinge en schriftelijke) communicatieve vaardigheden om je bevindingen op een professionele wijze over te brengen aan een academisch en/of professioneel publiek.</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: In deze cursus doen studenten op gevorderd niveau kennis op mbt de productie en distributie van film en televisie. Na afloop van de cursus hebben studenten een overzicht over de bestaande academische literatuur en over een aantal verschillende methodologische benaderingen. Zij kunnen deze binnen het wetenschappelijke debat plaatsen en zijn in staat om kritisch op bronnen en gepresenteerde data te reflecteren. Bovendien kunnen studenten een onderzoeksopzet uitwerken die een bijdrage levert aan het mediawetenschappelijke debat, specifiek voor het deelgebied van Media Industries Studies.

Studenten ontwikkelen vaardigheden middels het bijdragen aan een collectieve literatuurdatabase, het organiseren van een excursie en het inhoudelijk voorbereiden van panels met (professionele) gastsprekers.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Deze cursus over de media industrie richt zich op de productie en distributie van film en televisie. Studenten gaan middels literatuuronderzoek de institutionele context van productie en distributie bestuderen waarbij onder andere aan de orde gesteld wordt hoe digitalisering en conglomeratie de media industrie hebben veranderd. Studenten leren bovendien theoretische concepten en relevante methodes kennen om op academisch niveau onderzoek naar productie- en distributieprocessen te kunnen doen. Ook maken studenten aan de hand van een excursie en gastsprekers kennis met het Nederlandse medialandschap. In het verlengde daarvan wordt aandacht gevestigd op een kritische reflectie op de gepresenteerde data.

Deze cursus geeft inzicht in het werkveld binnen de media industrie. Middels excursies en workshopsmet gastsprekers leren studenten Nederlandse mediabedrijven kennen. Zij doen kennis op mbt. het organiseren en voorbereiden van werkveldpanels, biedt een voorbereiding op de stage (in blok 4).</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After finishing the course, the student is able to:
-analyze media industries from institutional, economic and cultural perspectives
-reflect on existing theories of media industries
-search, select, evaluate and analyze (published and oral) sources for research on media industries.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De media-industrie is een sector die in de afgelopen decennia behoorlijk gegroeid is. Achter-de-schermendocumentaires voor dvd's, het 'lokale' invullen van 'globale' televisieformats, games, korte webisodes en de activiteiten van fictionele personages op sociale media zorgen voor een samenwerking van mediabedrijven die vaak deel van een conglomeraat zijn.

In deze cursus onderzoeken wij de structuren en verwevenheid van de media-industrie. Wie zijn de spelers en hoe zijn de verschillende bedrijven en sectoren (bijv. film, televisie, muziek, games) met elkaar verweven?  Aan de hand van voorbeelden gaan wij de institutionele, economische en juridische contexten na die aan hedendaagse mediaproducten vorm geven. Er komen vragen aan bod zoals: welke aspecten bepalen de muziek die in films gebruikt wordt, welke afspraken bestaan voor het 'lokale' invullen van 'globale' televisieformats en waarom zijn televisieuitzendingen alleen voor beperkte tijd op internet terug te kijken?

Je doet in deze cursus kennis op van media-industriële structuren evenals van verschillende benaderingen en theorieën om de media-industrie te bestuderen. Bovendien leer je de werkwijze en werkgevers van het beroepsveld kennen waarin je na deze opleiding terecht zou kunnen komen. Toets 2 (paper) moet op zichzelf voldoende zijn afgerond.
Voor studenten LAS en TCS die deze cursus  volgen als deel van het kernpakket van hun hoofdrichting geldt een verplichte voorbereiding. Informatie: students.uu.nl/gw/tcs
Deze cursus is het 1e vak in Verdiepingspakket ‘Media, communicatie en markt’
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178552,2017,Media Wisdom: Media and Literacies in European Cultural History,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['S.L. Reinders'],,Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

-       De       student       heeft       kennis       van       en       reflecteert       kritisch       op       mediageletterdheid       in       diachroon       perspectiefkennis       van       en       reflecteert       kritisch       op       mediageletterdheid       in       diachroon       perspectief

- De student kan een       wetenschappelijk       artikel       doorgronden,       daarvan       een       leesvervangende       samenvatting       maken       (in       helder       en       correct       Nederlands)       en       de       gelezen       tekst       kritisch       beoordelen
- De student kan op       professionele       wijze       samenwerken       ter       voorbereiding       van       een       presentatie

-     De     student     is     in     staat     tot     het     geven     van     een     beknopte,     begrijpelijke     en     boeiende     presentatie     voor     een     publiek     van     'peers'.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Onder ‘mediawijsheid’ verstaan we alle kennis en vaardigheden die mensen nodig hebben om bewust, kritisch en actief deel te namen aan een wereld waarin media een belangrijke rol spelen. Deze cursus plaatst mediawijsheid in een diachroon perspectief, met als doel studenten vanuit verschillende invalshoeken kritisch te laten nadenken over de mediageschiedenis en de rol die mediawijsheid daarin speelt. Omdat nieuwe media vragen om nieuwe omgangsvormen, gaan mediarevoluties gepaard met ‘mediatraining’. Hoe zijn mensen in de loop van de geschiedenis ‘mediawijs’ geworden? En hoe heeft die wijsheid tot steeds weer nieuwe ontwikkelingen geleid? Door de  dynamiek van dit proces te bestuderen, krijgen studenten inzicht in cruciale momenten en ontwikkelingen in de mediageschiedenis, en ook in huidige debatten over lees- en schrijfprocessen, auteurschap en copyright in een digitaal tijdperk.

Net als de andere TOC’s in blok 1 bevat de cursus een uitgebreide training in academische vaardigheden: je leert een wetenschappelijk artikel lezen en samenvatten, je oefent samenwerken op professionele wijze en een goede presentatie maken en geven.
De TOC laat je kennis maken met de volgende hoofdrichtingen:
NB deze cursus is uitsluitend toegankelijk voor eerstejaars TCS
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178592,2017,Medical Ethics and Philosophy of Medicine,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['dr. L.L.E. Bolt'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of this course participants have the ability to:
• to recognize and critically analyse ethical issues in medicine and public health;
• to understand the major frameworks of ethical analysis and practical tools in biomedical and public health ethics for assessing these issues;
• to explain how particular arguments are related to more general normative ethical theories;
• to explain how anthropological assumptions and technological developments play a role in the moral debate;
• to adopt a clear position on a chosen ethical issue and to substantiate it (in a paper).</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Is euthanasia of demented patients in a progressed state morally permissible? Do we have a moral duty to develop and use enhancement technologies? What should government, industry and individuals do in order to tackle problems like obesity? Biomedical ethics is an interesting and complex branch of applied ethics. At the start of the course students will choose a specific ethical issue for an in-depth analysis. They will work during the course on this issue and scrutinize arguments in order to develop well-argued viewpoint or position resulting in a paper. During the course we will study the theoretical approaches, concepts, arguments and methods unnecessary to analyse these ethical issues including the influence of hidden (anthropological or moral) assumptions and technological developments within the different positions.

Career orientation: Students will learn what type of roles ethicists in the field of health care ethics play and the type of expertise needed. The achieved knowledge and skills are useful for a professional career in health care organizations as well academic ethics centers.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Dr.ir. Wilbert Bartels, UMC Utrecht/Imaging Division, lecturer
Dr. Arnold Schilham, UMC Utrecht/Imaging Division, lecturer
Dr.ir. Roel Deckers, UMC Utrecht/Imaging Division, lecturer
Dr.ir. Bastiaan van Nierop, UMC Utrecht/Imaging Division, lecturer

In this course the physics behind the most important medical imaging modalities will be treated. After an introductory lecture, x-ray imaging (radiography, fluoroscopy, digital subtraction angiography, computed tomography), ultrasound, nuclear imaging techniques (SPECT & PET) and magnetic resonance imaging will be discussed. The increasing importance of medical imaging for guiding surgery and minimally invasive radiological interventions will be emphasized. During the course, representative problems will be handed out and discussed.
“The essential Physics of medical Imaging”, authors: Bushberg, Boone, Leidholdt and seibert; 3rd revised edition ISBN-10: 1451118104
“Basic Principles of MR Imaging”; published by Philips Nederland (to be purchased from the Education Coordinator)
Apply at least 2 weeks before start of the course. Register via the study guide.

E-lectures are mainly given by professor Emma Jakoi of Duke University.
In this course the physiology and pathophsyiology of organs (heart, vasculature and kidney) are taught including their relations and interactions.

Students have to watch online lectures and are encouraged to check their level of understanding in a formative mini-quiz, which is organized in small e-modules provided in Blackboard. After every theme (Cardiovascular and Renal system) the student has to pass the formative test. Students are welcome to participate in practical skills training concerning the ECG.
Summative assessments are two midterm exams and one final test. These tests are similar to the exams of the bachelor course ‘Orgaansystemen’.
Teachers of this particular course are available to answer questions.
E-modules based on online lectures provided by Duke University are the main source of information.
Additional information can be read in Human Physiology, 5th- 6th edition, Silverthorn Pearson 2010.
Chapter 15: Blood Flow and Control of Blood Pressure

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Het doel van de cursus Medical Humanities  is van de student een betere arts te maken door te bereiken dat de student:

column2: • inzicht heeft in de condition humaine, complementair aan zijn biomedische kennis;
• beter inzicht heeft in de morele en juridische verantwoordelijkheden en plichten die artsen ten opzichte van hun  patiënten hebben;

• begrijpt dat de beoefening van de geneeskunst plaatsvindt in een culturele en sociale context die door diversiteit wordt gekenmerkt en begrijpt hoe die context mede vorm geeft aan de diverse beleving van ziekte en aan de wijze waarop de geneeskunst wordt beoefend;
• in het perspectief van bovengenoemde doelen de competenties observeren, analyseren, empathie en zelfreflectie verder heeft ontwikkeld.

column1: De cursus beslaat 6 weken en is onderverdeeld in drie clusters.

Cluster 1  Begint met een inleiding in de verschillende disciplines: gezondheidsrecht, sociologie, ethiek en filosofie. Daarna wordt het onderwijs interdisciplinair aangeboden rond de thema’s Wetenschappelijk onderzoek en Scientific Literacy.
Cluster 2  Omvat multidiciplinair onderwijs rond de thema’s Technologie, Schaartse en Preventie.
Cluster 3  Omvat multidisciplinair onderwijs rond de thema’s Einde van het leven, Arts-Patiënt relatie en Begin van het leven

In de cursus Medical Humanities wordt gebruik gemaakt van verschillende werkvormen. Er zijn 21 hoorcolleges, 15 werkgroepen en 4 werkcolleges. Er is een aanwezigheidsplicht (zie blokboek voor details).
Plaats van het blok in het curriculum
De cursus vindt plaats in jaar 3.
Het blok is gebaseerd op de volgende bronnen:
-    Blokboek Medical Humanities en de daarin genoemde literatuur
MH wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijke toets in week 6 en een beoordeling van een paper. Het cijfer voor het blok MH wordt voor 50% bepaald door het tentamen en 50% door de paper.
Contactpersoon en informatie: Prof. Dr. J.J.M. van Delden (examinator), j.j.m.vandelden@umcutrecht.nl

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182726,2017,Evidence based medicine,Dutch,Faculty of Science,,['dr. H. Gardarsdottir'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Na afronding van de cursus is de student in staat:

column2: • de belangrijkste klinisch farmacologische (fase I-III), farmaco-epidemiologische, biostatistische en farmaco-economische begrippen uit te leggen;
• de kwaliteit van experimenteel en observationeel geneesmiddelenonderzoek en farmaco-economisch onderzoek te beoordelen;

• het verschil uit te leggen tussen werkzaamheid en veiligheid zoals aangetoond in gerandomiseerd gecontroleerd klinisch onderzoek en effectiviteit en bijwerkingen zoals wordt gezien in de dagelijkse klinische praktijk;
• de factoren die van invloed zijn op het ontstaan van geneesmiddelenbeleid te beschrijven en deze factoren te kunnen wegen;

• op basis van de (on)bedoelde effecten zoals vastgesteld in geneesmiddelenonderzoek te beargumenteren voor welke subpopulaties in de dagelijkse praktijk de resultaten wel en voor welke deze mogelijk niet toepasbaar zijn (externe validiteit);
• op basis van gerapporteerd geneesmiddelenonderzoek farmacotherapeutische keuzes te maken en deze wetenschappelijk te onderbouwen;
• het spanningsveld tussen medicatiebeleid en individuele farmacotherapie te overzien;
• het gebruik van evidence voor het maken van beleid door stakeholders te beschrijven;

• een adequate onderzoeksvraag met bijbehorend onderzoeksplan te formuleren om de kwaliteit van farmacotherapeutisch beleid zelfstandig of naar aanleiding van gemaakte afspraken met behulp van prescriptiegegevens te analyseren;
• gemaakte geneesmiddelkeuzes in een gesprek met collegae toe te lichten, hierin open te staan voor andere standpunten en deze zorgvuldig te wegen;
• schriftelijk eigen beleidsmatige geneesmiddelkeuzes met valide argumenten te onderbouwen;
• mogelijke conflicts of interest en (wetenschappelijke) integriteit van onderzoekers en betrokkenen bij geneesmiddelonderzoek en beleidsbeslissingen te beschrijven en deze kritisch te beschouwen.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Tijdens de levenscyclus van een geneesmiddel speelt besluitvorming op basis van evidence over de (kosten-)effectiviteit en veiligheid van het betreffende geneesmiddel een belangrijke rol. Grofweg kunnen daarbij twee situaties worden onderscheiden: besluitvorming door beleidsmakers op (inter)nationaal niveau over toelating en vergoeding van geneesmiddelen en besluitvorming ten aanzien van toepassing in de klinische praktijk: het maken van farmacotherapeutische keuzes. In dit blok komt de student achtereenvolgens met beide situaties in aanraking.

In de eerste helft van de cursus verkrijgt de student basale kennis en vaardigheden op het gebied van farmaco-epidemiologie en farmaco-economie. Daarnaast krijgt de student in deze periode vooral inzicht in besluitvorming op basis van evidence ten aanzien van toelating en vergoeding van geneesmiddelen. Aan de hand van één specifieke casus (bijv. nieuw middel hepatitis of COPD of nieuw oncolyticum) wordt de student geconfronteerd met het perspectief van de patiënt en beleidsmakers (scoping: welke eindpunten zijn van belang en welke evidence zou je willen hebben) en gaat hij zelf kritisch kijken naar onderzoeken die ten behoeve van besluitvorming zijn ingediend (RCTs en farmaco-economische analyses) en de bijbehorende rapporten van registratie- en vergoedingsautoriteiten. CHMP vergaderingen en ZIN vergaderingen worden nagebootst om studenten te laten oefenen met argumenteren en ervaren hoe evidence wordt meegenomen in deze besluitvorming. Daarbij moet de student beleidsmatige keuzes met valide argumenten onderbouwen. Aan het eind van dit gedeelte van de cursus zal experts gevraagd worden om hun ervaringen in deze gremia te delen.

In de tweede helft van de cursus gaat de student zelf aan de slag met het uitwerken van één specifieke vraagstelling, waarbij op basis van gerapporteerd geneesmiddelenonderzoek farmacotherapeutische keuzes moeten worden gemaakt t.b.v. beleid op “lokaal” niveau (formularium of andere beleidsafspraken 1e lijnszorg of instelling). Hierbij gaan studenten ook aan de slag met prescriptiegegevens: zij formuleren een adequate vraagstelling om de kwaliteit van gemaakte afspraken rondom hun vraagstelling met behulp van prescriptiegegevens te analyseren. Ook is er op het gebied van mondelinge communicatie specifieke aandacht voor argumenteren: het helder verwoorden van het eigen standpunt en wetenschappelijke argumenten, de standpunten van de ander doorgronden en daarvoor openstaan en het zorgvuldig afwegen hiervan.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/183110,2017,Medicinal Chemistry,English,Faculty of Science,,['dr. ir. D.T.S. Rijkers'],,Course goals
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

At the       end       of       this       course       you       will       have       gained       an       insight       into       the       organic       synthesis       and       effects       of       complex       drugs       (for       treating       amyloid       diseases,       thrombosis,       microbial/viral       infections,       cancer       and       bronchial       diseases).

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: The 20th century medical revolution was largely instigated by the discovery of new drugs. Medicinal chemistry deals with the discovery, design, identification and synthesis of drugs, and also with the study of the relationships between the structure of a drug and its behaviour in the body. The field of medicinal chemistry is rooted in chemistry, but also uses various other disciplines, such as biology, medicine and pharmacy. By discovering new and innovative drugs, medicinal chemistry has been pushing the boundaries of science. Proper strategies require insight into physiological and patho-physiological, pharmacological and biochemical processes. Besides, medicinal chemists search for sample structures (lead compounds) in nature (pharmacognosy), in various organic molecule files (compound libraries) or by using the computer (computational modelling). Molecular recognition and the key-lock principle determine what a drug achieves in the body (pharmacological effect) and how a drug is processed by and excreted from the body. This behaviour (absorption, distribution, metabolism, excretion and toxicity) is determined by the physical-chemical properties of a drug.
By looking at five major diseases, the organic synthesis and pharmacology of a number of drugs for treating these diseases will be explored.
By way of conclusion, thematic lectures will draw a picture of the work of a medicinal chemist.

column2: </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182393,2017,Medicinal Chemistry,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. E.E. Moret', 'dr. ir. D.T.S. Rijkers']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, the student understands the concepts of medicinal chemistry and can apply this understanding to solve real problems, designing a drug candidate.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Innovative drug research has a drug discovery and a drug development phase. In the drug discovery phase, chemists, or more precise, medicinal chemists make molecules and biologists, or more precise, pharmacologists, test these molecules. Both fields can be studied in the final year.

In this chemical course, we challenge the student to think of a medical need, to find a target, to come up with a lead and to optimise this lead towards a drug candidate. While performing this project, the students will learn about medicinal chemistry, organic chemistry, biochemistry and computational chemistry.

The course starts by learning from the past. Two students orally present a small molecule drug monograph. In parallel, these teams of two start a drug design project. This consists of several steps. Finding a disease, that poses an unmet medical need. Following that, the teams select a target biomacromolecule, select a lead compound and optimise this lead for drug candidate development. The project results will be presented in a written report. The medicinal chemistry concepts will be assessed individually in an open book exam. The student can consult either an organic chemistry, biochemistry or medicinal chemistry book during the exam.
The following course components are used to reach the learning aims.
- Drug monograph presentation: The birth of a ‘first in class’ drug.
A team of two selects a first-in-class drug for an oral presentation

column2: • target finding
• enzyme structure and function
• receptor structure and function
• ion channel structure and function
• ligand disposition
• ligand-target binding
• ligand optimisation
• ligand synthesis

column1: Lectures about the workshops will be given after the workshops. There are also some guest lectures.

A team of two students works on a drug design project. The project involves finding a target molecule with defined 3D structure, docking a lead molecule, optimising this lead for improved affinity, selectivity and pharmacokinetics. The results are presented in a written scientific report.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182580,2017,Medicinal chemistry: the organic chemistry of drug synthesis,English,Faculty of Science,,[],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>At the end of this course you will have gained insight into the organic synthesis of complex drug-like molecules that are currently used for treatment of diseases like infection, cancer, diabetes, thrombosis, anxiety, and Alzheimer.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

According to the IUPAC recommendations in 1998, ‘Medicinal Chemistry’ is defined as: “Medicinal Chemistry is a chemistry-based discipline, also involving aspects of biological, medical, and pharmaceutical sciences. It is concerned with the invention, discovery, design, identification, and preparation of biologically active compounds, the study of their metabolism, the interpretation of their mode of action at the molecular level, and the construction of structure-activity relationships.” In this course all aspects of Medicinal Chemistry will be discussed (during lectures and work-sessions), although with a strong emphasis on drug design and synthesis, inspired by the most significant molecules now used in modern medicine, like: cyclosporine, maraviroc, oseltamivir, imatinib, epothilone, enalapril, and paroxetine.

The course starts with a short recapitulation of the most important items as learned in the Organic Chemistry 2 course, followed by the introduction of retrosynthetic analysis, one-group C-X disconnections, functional group interconversions (FGI), and 1,2- respectively 1,3-disconnections for the synthesis of C-X and C-C bonds. Then, protecting group strategy is discussed and applied for the synthesis of peptides (including amide bond formation), either in solution or on the solid support. Based on solid phase organic synthesis, combinatorial chemistry, parallel synthesis, and library design is discussed, and some approaches to achieve high chemical diversity (multicomponent reactions, diverted total synthesis) will be used as important examples for lead finding and optimization. Important carbon-carbon formation reactions, Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions, and Ru-based ring-closing metathesis will be exemplified and discussed. Finally, reaction optimization of initial laboratory routes toward large-scale industrial processes will be the last topic of this course.

Written exam (60%); Drug Monograph: ‘The birth and life of a first-in-class drug’; a written report (30%) followed by a short oral presentation (10%) to discuss the results with the teacher and students.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182372,2017,Medieval History: 400-1500,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. A.B. Adamska'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this course students will be able to:
- outline the main political, religious, economic, and cultural developments of the medieval period;
- understand the medieval roots of many of the institutions and ideas that shape our own world;
- apply basic skills in historical research and in oral and written communication.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Conventionally speaking, the Middle Ages are considered to cover the centuries between the
years 400 and 1500. The concept of the Middle Ages refers, primarily, to a European
phenomenon, although regions in the Byzantine and Islamic world come into the story as well.
As common prejudice has it, the medieval period stands out most of all by a reversion to
barbarism in which human progress came to a grinding halt: people lost the ability to read and
write and even simple technologies like the fabrication of bricks were forgotten.
This course shows that there is no such thing as ‘the’ Middle Ages but rather four consecutive
periods: Late Antiquity, the Early Middle Ages, the High Middle Ages, and finally the Late
Middle Ages. All four periods were characterized by constant processes of change, by
outbursts of creativity and inventiveness—but also by war, invasions, and diseases that wiped
out large parts of the European population. Students will find that barbarians were not all that
barbarian, that those who entered a monastery were no sad cases of religious mania, that
medieval kings in their right minds did not order to have their rivals' heads chopped off on a
whim, and that medieval peasants and townspeople were perfectly capable of making rational
There are two classes each week, in which either segments of the handbook or recent articles
and primary sources are discussed. Students prepare an oral presentation (ca. 15 minutes) and
an essay (ca. 2,500 words) for this course.

Practical skills of academic writing and analytic reading will be tested through short written assignments which should be handed in before every class and will concern the subject of the day’s lecture.

Students are further tested in one final exam at the end of the course. It’s a take-home exam, including material from the handbook and from the reader as well as topics discussed in the classroom. It consists of four essay-questions, for which knowledge of the handbook is needed as well, but also draws on the student’s ability to handle both primary sources and secondary literature.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course a broad selection of primary texts across a range  of Medieval Irish genres will be read and interpreted. Relevant articles from the secondary literature dealing with a range of literary genres will also be read and evaluated. In addition to reading Medieval Irish texts, the course will also deal with the question of textual edition and edition production in Medieval Irish and will discuss and evaluate the current practices for creating such editions which exist in the field.

Students who have successfully completed this course:
(1)  Will be able to translate accurately Medieval Irish and Welsh texts
(2)  Will be able to analyze and compare Medieval Irish and Welsh texts
(3)  Will have gained a higher degree of knowledge of medieval Irish and Welsh genres
(4)  Will be able to discuss and evaluate conflicting hypotheses

Similar     medieval     Irish     and     Welsh     genre     texts     such     as     law,     saints'     lives,     narrative     prose,      poetry     will     be     translated.     The     texts     will     be     analysed     and     compared     from     the     viewpoint     of     language,     structure     and     themes.     The     cultural     background     to     the     genres     in     Ireland     and     Wales     shall     be     discussed,     analysed     and     compared.

column3: Hands-on experience of research on medieval manuscripts, leading in due course to a catalogue of the fragments in the University Library and exhibitions of groups of these fragments.</body>

column2: <head>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: The University Library possesses hundreds of fragments of medieval manuscripts, many of which come from book bindings. These fragments have never been studied. We will investigate them, trying to date and localise them and to write the history of the individual fragments. We will also study their contents, trying to identify the texts, and, in some cases, visual images and musical annotation contained in them. The results of our efforts will form the basis of a catalogue. We will also use our results in due course in a series of exhibitions.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column3: The successful participant has acquired the skills necessary to study medieval texts in manuscript. The participant will be able to go beyond the printed editions of both narrative and documentary texts, giving him the basic tools to read medieval bookhand and cursive. The course presupposes some knowledge of Latin, as most of the texts chosen have been written in that language. Completion of the course gives access to the course Medieval Written Culture.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A series of reading exercises, enabling students to acquire the ability to read medieval scripts used both in single sheet documents and books. The texts are mainly written in Latin. Background is also provided on the systems of abbreviation and punctuation, on palaeography, diplomatic and chronology.
Skills in transcribing medieval texts in manuscript, mainly in Latin.</body>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182282,2017,Medieval Welsh Texts and Philology,English,Faculty of Humanities,,['A. Griffith', 'dr. F. van den Eijnde']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
- have an improved capacity for reading and interpreting Medieval Welsh
- they have gained the ability to create and to use a textual edition

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course a broad selection of primary texts across a range of Medieval Welsh genres will be read and interpreted. Relevant articles from the secondary literature dealing with a range of literary genres will also be read and evaluated. In addition to reading Medieval Welsh texts, the course will also deal with the question of textual edition and edition production in Medieval Welsh and will discuss and evaluate the current practices for creating such editions which exist in the field.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Examinator: Dr. ir. P.R. Seevinck                                Timeslot: A+D

Medische beeldvormende technieken vormen in de hedendaagse klinische praktijk een onmisbaar onderdeel van de diagnostiek. Zo maken scantechnieken het bijvoorbeeld mogelijk om vele vormen van kanker op te sporen en de uitgebreidheid van de tumor te visualiseren. Steeds vaker wordt dergelijke informatie niet alleen gebruikt voor diagnostiek, maar ook voor het plannen en evalueren van verschillende vormen van therapie. Alle beeldvormende technieken berusten op de fysische interactie van een bepaalde vorm van energie (bijvoorbeeld röntgenstraling, elektromagnetische velden of geluid) met het menselijk lichaam. In dit blok wordt de fysica achter de belangrijkste medische beeldvormende technieken behandeld:

·          Klassieke Röntgentechnieken. Er wordt aandacht geschonken aan de geschiedenis en de aard van röntgenstraling en het gebruik hiervan in de klinische praktijk. Vervolgens wordt de techniek van de klassieke radiografie en van digitale subtractie angiografie (DSA) besproken.

·          Geavanceerde Röntgentechnieken. Hier staat het gebruik van projectie-reconstructie technieken voor tomografische beeldvorming met röntgenstraling centraal. De verschillende generaties computer tomografie (CT) scanners worden behandeld en een groot aantal voorbeelden van klinische toepassingen passeren de revue.

·          Nucleaire Beeldvorming. Dit deel van het blok gaat over het afbeelden van de functie van organen door gebruik te maken van radioactieve tracerstoffen die in het lichaam worden ingespoten. Aan bod komen planar scintigraphy, single photon emission computer tomography (SPECT) en positron emission tomography (PET).

·          Veiligheidsaspecten van ioniserende straling. Er wordt aandacht geschonken aan de verschillende soorten ioniserende straling en aan het begrip patiëntendosis. Vervolgens worden de biologische effecten van ioniserende straling en de hiermee samenhangende risico’s besproken.

·          Ultrageluid. Het mechanisme voor het opwekken en ontvangen van ultrageluid en de interactie van ultrageluid met weefsel in het menselijk lichaam komen aan bod en is er aandacht voor toepassingen en beeldartefacten.
·          Magnetic Resonance Imaging. Vanwege de complexiteit van deze techniek zal MRI een groter aantal (werk)-colleges beslaan dan de overige technieken. Achtereenvolgens zullen aan bod komen:
-          de fysica van nucleaire magnetische resonantie en de instrumentatie van een MRI scanner;
-          het mechanisme van beeldvorming met MRI;
-          praktische aspecten van MRI: hoe scant men beelden van voldoende diagnostische waarde?;
De vereiste voorkennis is natuurkunde op VWO niveau.
Aan het eind van het blok is de student in staat:
·          de fysische principes achter de belangrijkste medische beeldvormende technieken te beschrijven;
·          de voor- en nadelen van de beeldvormende technieken voor verschillende medische toepassingen te benoemen;
·          de aan de beeldvormende technieken verbonden veiligheidsaspecten te beschrijven.
Aan het eind van het blok is de student in staat:
·          de opgedane kennis te gebruiken voor het beoordelen van medische beelden en artefacten daarin;
·          kritisch te beoordelen of een klinische wetenschappelijke vraag met beeldvormende technieken kan worden beantwoord en met welke technieken;
Hoorcolleges, gevolgd door werkcolleges waarin de stof in opgaven zal worden behandeld. Contacttijd:40%.

Ongeveer halverwege de cursus wordt er een schriftelijke tussentijdse toets afgenomen over de tot dan toe behandelde stof. Het resultaat van deze toets telt voor 20% mee in het eindresultaat. Het eindcijfer wordt voor de overige 80% bepaald door het resultaat van het individuele schriftelijke tentamen waarmee het blok wordt afgesloten.
·          Handouts en alle opdrachten worden tijdens de (werk)colleges verstrekt;
·          “Basic Principles of MR Imaging” (Philips Medical Systems) is bij de docenten te koop.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/178717,2017,Plurilingualism & Mediation: Intercultural Competence,Dutch, English",Faculty of Humanities,,"['dr. G. Cascio', 'K.E. Schoutsen']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The overall aim of this course is to discuss theories regarding intercultural interaction, as well as to experience actual international team work and reflecting upon these interactions. As such it will enhance your self-awareness, intercultural competences and the ability to understand, as well as and mediate between, different perspectives. In addition you will work in international groups towards a national and supranational group report, the theme of which will be announced during the course. Finally, you will also work on an interactive presentation of you group work via a making of.

column2: • is able to formulate the conditions for (successful) intercultural cooperation and the development of intercultural competence; develops competencies for efficient and meaningful collaboration..
• manages to participate in an (partly online) international group project, while making use of diverse digital tools and successfully completing assignments and delivering end-products;
• enhances awareness, understanding, and skills necessary to work (collaborate, communicate) in a diverse world;
• is aware of his/her own (cultural) perspectives and how this influences his/her interaction with students from other (or their own) cultures;
• is able to reflect critically on the collaboration within the project;
• becomes aware of super-diversity in intercultural communicative exchanges in a highly globalised society;
• learns to deal with ambiguity (the ability to accept lack of clarity and ambiguity and to be able to deal with it constructively).
• enhances behavioural flexibility (the ability to adapt one’s own behaviour to different requirements and situations)
• develops understanding for otherness (Curiosity and openness, readiness to suspend disbelief about other cultures and belief about one’s own).

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Globalisation and technological developments have made intercultural contact and cooperation considerably easier. Intercultural contexts are getting increasingly more diverse which causes behaviours and identifications of individuals to continually be less predictable. Superdiverse contexts ask for specific skills that are not directly focused on the contact with one specific culture, but with people from other cultures in general and with intercultural contexts with great cultural diversity. Because of technological developments people can come together and work together more easily.

The ability to operate successfully in intercultural contexts depends on specific competences. During this course we will focus on such abilities and competences, both from a theoretical and an experiential perspective. Intercultural competences are generally claimed to be best developed during real/life interaction with ´the other´ and through continuous reflection on your own perspective and the perspectives and perceptions of the other.

During this course you will acquire knowledge and gain actual experience in working in modern intercultural contexts. You will work in an international team and organize multiple meetings with your group and will work collectively on a final assignment. The focus in this course is on the ability to reflect on your own functioning in a diverse context, intercultural as well as institutional. A lot of attention will be paid to your own intercultural awareness and capabilities, as well as how international educational contexts can contribute to its development.

The ability to operate successfully in plurilingual and intercultural contexts depends on specific competences. During this course we will focus on such ability and competences, both from a theoretical and an experiential perspective. Intercultural competences are generally claimed to be best developed during real-life interaction with ‘the other’ and through continuously reflecting on these interactions.
Only students who have been admitted to MA programme in Intercultural Communication can enroll in the course Plurilingualism & Mediation: Intercultural Competence.
